parts.text:
[Statement 1]: There is limited evidence specifically about cost-effective methods for reducing human-primate conflict in agricultural areas.
[Statement 2]: There is no evidence from systematic studies evaluating the effectiveness of using unpalatable buffer crops as a primate-specific deterrent.
[Statement 3]: There is no evidence from systematic studies evaluating the effectiveness of mechanical barriers like fences and ditches as a primate-specific deterrent.
[Statement 4]: There is no evidence from systematic studies evaluating the effectiveness of paying farmers to cover costs of non-harmful deterrent strategies.
[Statement 5]: There is no evidence from systematic studies evaluating the effectiveness of planting crops favoured by primates away from primate areas.
[Statement 6]: There is no evidence from systematic studies evaluating the effectiveness of compensating farmers for produce loss.
[Statement 7]: Some general mammal deterrent methods that could apply to primates show evidence of effectiveness.
[Statement 8]: Using chili-based deterrents showed mixed results as a mammal deterrent.
[Statement 9]: Chili-spray, chili smoke, chili fences and chili extract have been found to repel elephants, at least initially.
[Statement 10]: Some studies found chili smoke and chili fences did not reduce crop raiding.
[Statement 11]: Using loud noises as a deterrent showed variable effectiveness.
[Statement 12]: Loud noises activated when animals were in the vicinity reduced crop damage by deer and elephants.
[Statement 13]: Regularly sounding loud noises did not repel rabbits or deer.
[Statement 14]: Fire deterrents showed some effectiveness in reducing crop damage.
[Statement 15]: Studies found fire reduced crop damage by elephants.
[Statement 16]: Large fires combined with people and drums repelled elephants faster than other combinations.
[Statement 17]: Drones showed promise as a deterrent for large mammals.
[Statement 18]: Drones were found to repel elephants from crops within one minute.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What is the most cost-effective method for reducing human-primate conflict in agricultural areas?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Primate reintroduction success rates show considerable variation by region.
[Statement 2]: In Africa, chimpanzee reintroduction programs demonstrated mixed results.
[Statement 3]: In Guinea and the Republic of Congo, the majority of reintroduced chimpanzees survived for 1-5 years.
[Statement 4]: In The Gambia, a reintroduced chimpanzee population increased by 38% over 25 years.
[Statement 5]: In another case in The Gambia, a reintroduced chimpanzee population increased 25 years after reintroduction.
[Statement 6]: Western gorilla programs in Gabon and the Republic of Congo showed that the majority of the gorillas survived for at least 9 months to 4 years.
[Statement 7]: In Indonesian studies, all Sumatran orangutans survived for at least 3 months after reintroduction.
[Statement 8]: In one Malaysian study, orangutan populations showed 98% survival after release.
[Statement 9]: In another Malaysian study, an orangutan population showed a decline of 33% over 33 years.
[Statement 10]: In South America, Brazilian studies on primate reintroduction showed mixed outcomes.
[Statement 11]: Golden lion tamarin programs in Brazil reported that most reintroduced individuals did not survive over 7 years.
[Statement 12]: Other Brazilian studies found that golden lion tamarin populations declined after reintroduction.
[Statement 13]: In Madagascar, studies found that primate populations persisted 4-55 years after reintroduction.
[Statement 14]: In Madagascar, most black-and-white ruffed lemurs with limited free-ranging experience died over 5 years.
[Statement 15]: In Belize, primate reintroduction recorded population increases 5 years after reintroduction.
[Statement 16]: Thailand showed primate population declines post-reintroduction.
[Statement 17]: African studies generally showed higher long-term survival rates for great apes.
[Statement 18]: Asian orangutan programs showed variable results.
[Statement 19]: South American primate reintroduction programs had more mixed outcomes.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__How does the success rate of primate reintroduction programs vary between different continents?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: No studies were found that directly evaluate the impact of plastic pollution in waterways on primate populations that live near rivers.
[Statement 2]: A search revealed several related actions, including the removal of debris from freshwater marshes, freshwater swamps, and brackish/saline swamps.
[Statement 3]: No studies have been found that evaluate the effects of debris removal on vegetation.
[Statement 4]: No studies were found evaluating the effects on marine and freshwater mammal populations from limiting the discharge of solid waste overboard from vessels.
[Statement 5]: No studies were found evaluating the effects on benthic invertebrate populations from limiting the discharge of solid waste overboard from vessels.
[Statement 6]: No studies were found evaluating the effects on marine and freshwater mammal populations from removing and cleaning up shoreline waste disposal sites.
[Statement 7]: Actions related to primate management include installing primate-proof garbage bins.
[Statement 8]: No evidence was found for the effects of installing primate-proof garbage bins on primate populations.
[Statement 9]: The specific intersection of plastic pollution in waterways and impacts on riverine primate populations has not been systematically studied according to database searches.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What is the impact of plastic pollution in waterways on primate populations that live near rivers?
